GAME CHARACTERISTICS

Volleyball is a sport played by two teams on a court divided by a net.
There are different versions for specific circumstances to enable
people of all kinds to enjoy the game.

The object of the game is to send the ball over the net so that it
lands in the opponent’s court, and to prevent the same effort by the
opponent. The team has three hits to return the ball (in addition to
a block contact).

The rally begins with a service: the server hits the ball over the net
to the opponent. The rally continues until the ball lands on the court,
goes "out", or a team fails to return the ball properly.

In volleyball, the team that wins a rally scores a point (Rally Point
System).

When the receiving team wins a rally, it scores a point and gains the
right to serve, and its players rotate one position clockwise.

THE TEXT OF THE REGULATIONS
PART 1: PHILOSOPHY OF THE RULES AND REFEREEING

Volleyball is in every respect one of the world’s top sports – it has more
affiliated federations, more television viewers, more followers on social
media, more registered players and recreational participants than almost
any other sport, and a dynamic, clean and colourful image that combines
high-level performance sport and show.

William Morgan, the inventor of the game, would still recognize it today,
because volleyball has retained certain characteristic and essential
elements over the years. Some of these it shares with other net / ball /
racket games: service, rotation (alternate serving), attack, defence, and
players who can play both at the net and in the back of the court. But the
sport has evolved: it is explosive, spectacular, fast and flowing, with
athletic players doing sensational things on the court in packed arenas.

Moreover, volleyball is unique among net games because the ball is
constantly in the air – a flying ball.

… and each team has a certain amount of internal passing before the
ball must be returned to the opponent.

In recent years, the FIVB has made great progress in adapting the
game to a modern audience by liberalizing the criteria for ball
handling, introducing up to two specialized defensive players
(Liberos), implementing technology with the Video Challenge System
that fairly evaluates the athletes’ efforts, and promoting a policy that
encourages a flowing game to entertain the audience both in the hall
and on screen.

This text is addressed to a wide volleyball audience – players,
coaches, referees, spectators, commentators and others – because
an understanding of the rules enables better play and personal
satisfaction. Coaches can develop better team structure and tactics
and give players the opportunity to fully develop their skills, and an
understanding of the relationship between the written rules and the
actual actions on the court enables officials to make better decisions.

Volleyball is both a recreational and a competitive sport. Recreational
play appeals to the human spirit and promotes “fun” and a healthy
life. In competition, people can demonstrate their skills, creativity,
freedom of expression and fighting spirit. The rules are designed and
structured so that

all these facets can develop.

THE REFEREE IN THIS CONTEXT

The essence of a good referee lies in the concepts of fairness, justice
and consistency (the position in the middle between the two courts is a
symbol of balance). Together, they enable the players to trust the
referee’s actions. However, the referee should be more of a facilitator
than a controller, more a conductor than a dictator, more an efficient
promoter than an “efficient” punisher.

By understanding why a rule was created and being clear about its
purpose within the framework of the “show”, the referee becomes an
important part of the overall successful production, while remaining
largely in the background and intervening only when necessary. We
can say that a good referee will use the rules to make the competition a
fulfilling experience for all involved.

Those who have read this far should regard the following rules as the
current stage in the evolution of a great game, but should also
consider why the preceding paragraphs may be equally important to
you in your own role within the sport.

Get involved!
Stay with the game!
Understand the game!

SECTION 1: THE GAME

1 PLAYING AREA
1.1 DIMENSIONS

1.2 PLAYING SURFACE

CHAPTER 1
FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT

The playing surface includes the playing court and the free zone. It
must be rectangular and symmetrical.

The playing court is a rectangle measuring 18 x 9 m, surrounded by a
free zone at least 3 m wide on all sides.

The free playing space is the space above the playing surface that is
free of any obstacles. The height of the free playing space is at least
7 m from the playing surface.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the free zone must extend
5 m from the sidelines and 6.5 m from the end lines. The free
playing space must be at least 12.5 m high, measured from the
playing surface.

1.2.1 The surface must be flat, horizontal and uniform. It must not
pose a risk of injury to the players. Playing on rough or slippery
surfaces is forbidden.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, only a wooden or synthetic
surface is allowed. Any surface must be previously approved by the
FIVB.

1.2.2 For indoor courts, the surface of the playing court must be a
light colour.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, white colours are
required for the lines. Other, contrasting colours are required for
the playing court and the free zone. The court may be executed in
different colours to distinguish the front and back zones.

1.2.3 For outdoor courts, a slope of 5 mm per metre is allowed for
drainage.

Court lines made of rigid materials are forbidden.
See Rules 1.1, D1a, D1b, D2.

PART 2 – SECTION 1: THE GAME

1.3 LINES ON THE COURT

1.3.1 All lines are 5 cm wide. They must be of a light colour and
must be different from the colour of the floor and from all other lines.

1.3.2 Boundary lines
Two sidelines and two end lines mark the playing court. Both the
sidelines and end lines are drawn inside the dimensions of the court.

1.3.3 Centre line
The axis of the centre line divides the playing court into two equal
courts of 9 x 9 m each; however, the whole width of the line is
considered as belonging equally to both courts. This line extends
under the net from sideline to sideline.

1.3.4 Attack line
On each court, an attack line whose rear edge is 3 m from the axis of
the centre line marks the front zone.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the attack line is extended
by the addition of broken lines from the sidelines, consisting of five
short lines 15 cm long and 5 cm wide, spaced 20 cm apart, to a total
length of 1.75 m.

1.4 ZONES AND AREAS

1.4.1 Front zone
On each court, the front zone is limited by the axis of the centre line
and the rear edge of the attack line.

The front zone is considered to extend beyond the sidelines to the end
of the free zone.

1.4.2 Service zone
The service zone is a 9 m wide area behind each end line.

It is laterally limited by two short lines, each 15 cm long, drawn
20 cm behind the end line as extensions of the sidelines. The two
short lines are included in the width of the service zone.

In depth, the service zone extends to the end of the free zone.

1.4.3 Substitution zone
The substitution zone is limited by the extensions of the two attack
lines up to the scorer’s table.

1.4.4 Libero replacement zone
The Libero replacement zone is part of the free zone on the side of the
team benches, limited by the extension of the attack line to the end
line.

1.4.5 Warm-up area
For FIVB, world and official competitions, the warm-up areas,
measuring approximately 3 x 3 m, are located in the two bench corners
outside the free zone, where they do not obstruct the spectators’ view,
or alternatively behind the team bench where the stands start more
than 2.5 m from the playing surface.

1.5 TEMPERATURE
The minimum temperature may not be lower than 10° C (50° F).

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the maximum temperature is
set for each match by the FIVB Technical Delegate.

1.6 LIGHTING
The lighting should not be less than 300 lux.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the lighting on the playing
surface should not be less than 2000 lux, measured 1 m above the
playing surface.

2 NET AND POSTS

2.1 HEIGHT OF THE NET

2.1.1 A net is placed vertically above the centre line, with the top set at
2.43 m for men and 2.24 m for women.

2.1.2 Its height is measured from the centre of the court. The net height
(at the two sidelines) must be exactly the same and may not exceed the
official height by more than 2 cm.

2.2 STRUCTURE

The net is 1 m wide (± 3 cm) and 9.50 to 10 m long (with 25 to 50 cm
on each side beyond the sidelines), and is made of black squares
meshing 10 cm.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the mesh may be modified
in accordance with specific competition regulations to facilitate
advertising according to marketing agreements.

A 7 cm wide horizontal white band of folded canvas is sewn along the
entire length of the top of the net. At each end of the band there is a
hole through which a cord passes, used to fasten the band to the posts
and keep the top tight.

Inside the band, a flexible cable fastens the net to the posts and keeps
it taut at the top.

At the bottom of the net there is another horizontal band, 5 cm wide,
similar to the upper band, through which a cord is threaded. This cord
fastens the net to the posts and keeps the lower part taut.

Two white bands are attached vertically to the net directly above each
sideline.
They are 5 cm wide and 1 m long and are considered part of the net.

An antenna is a flexible rod 1.80 m long and 10 mm in diameter, made
of fibreglass or similar material.

An antenna is attached to the outer edge of each side band. The
antennas are placed on opposite sides of the net.

The upper 80 cm of each antenna extend above the net and are marked
with 10 cm stripes in contrasting colours, preferably red and white.

The antennas are considered part of the net and delimit the crossing
space laterally.

2.5 POSTS

2.5.1 The posts supporting the net are placed at a distance of
0.50–1.00 m outside the sidelines. They are 2.55 m high and preferably
adjustable.

For all FIVB, world and official competitions, the posts supporting the
net are placed 1 m outside the sidelines and must be padded.

2.5.2 The posts are rounded and smooth and are fixed to the floor
without wires. No dangerous or obstructing devices are permitted.

2.6 ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT

All additional equipment is specified by the FIVB regulations.

3 BALLS

3.1 STANDARDS
3.2 UNIFORMITY OF THE BALLS
3.3 BALL-RETRIEVAL SYSTEM

The ball must be spherical and made of a flexible leather or synthetic
leather cover with a bladder made of rubber or a similar material.

Its colour may be a uniform light colour or a combination of colours.

The synthetic leather material and the colour combinations of balls
used in official international competitions must conform to FIVB
standards.

Its circumference is 65–67 cm and its weight 260–280 g.

Its internal pressure must be 0.30 to 0.325 kg/cm² (4.26 to 4.61 psi)
(294.3 to 318.82 mbar or hPa).

All balls used in a match must have the same standards in terms of
circumference, weight, pressure, type, colour, etc.

FIVB, world and official competitions, as well as national or league
championships, must be played with balls approved by the FIVB,
unless otherwise agreed by the FIVB.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, five balls must be used. In
this case, six ball retrievers are positioned, one at each corner of the
free zone and one behind each referee.

PART 2 – SECTION 1: THE GAME

4 TEAMS

CHAPTER 2
PARTICIPANTS

4.1 TEAM COMPOSITION

4.1.1 A team may consist of up to 12 players, plus
– Coaching staff: one coach and up to two assistant coaches,

– Medical staff: one team therapist and one doctor.

Only those listed on the score sheet are normally allowed to enter the
competition / control area and to take part in the official warm-up and
the match.

For FIVB, world and official senior competitions:
– Up to 14 players may be entered on the score sheet and take part in a
  match.

The maximum of five officials on the bench (including the coach) are
chosen by the coach but must be listed on the score sheet and entered
on the O-2(bis) form.

The team manager and/or team journalist may not sit on or behind the
bench in the control area.

Any doctor or team therapist used at FIVB, world and official
competitions must be part of the official delegation and must have
been previously accredited by the FIVB. At FIVB, world and official
senior competitions, if they do not sit on the team bench, they must sit
on the boundary line within the competition control area or in a
special place specified in the specific competition handbook, and may
intervene only when requested by the referees to attend to an
emergency of a player.

The team attendant (even if not sitting on the bench) may help with the
warm-up at the net until the start of the official warm-up.

The official regulations for each event are contained in the
handbook for the competition.

4.1.2 One of the players is the team captain, who must be indicated on
the score sheet.

4.1.3 Only the players entered on the score sheet are allowed to enter the
playing area and take part in the match. Once the coach and the team
captain have signed the score sheet (team list for the electronic score
sheet), the listed players may no longer be changed.

4.2 TEAM AREA

4.2.1 Players who are not in play should either sit on their team bench or
stay in their warm‑up area. The coach and the other team members sit
on the bench, but may leave it temporarily.

The team benches are located next to the scorer’s table, outside the
free zone.

4.2.2 Only members of the team line‑up are allowed to enter the playing
area, sit on the bench during the match, and take part in the official
warm‑up.

4.2.3 Players who are not in play may warm up without balls as follows:
4.2.3.1 during the match: in the warm‑up areas;
4.2.3.2 during time‑outs: in the free zone behind their court.

4.2.4 During the official intervals, players may warm up with balls within
their own free zone.

4.3 EQUIPMENT

A player’s equipment consists of a jersey, shorts, socks (the uniform)
and sports shoes.

4.3.1 The colour and design of the jerseys, shorts and socks must be
uniform for the whole team (except for the Libero). Jerseys must be
clean.

4.3.2 The shoes must be light and flexible, with rubber or composite soles
without heels.

4.3.3 Players’ jerseys must be numbered from 1 to 20.

For FIVB, world and official senior competitions where larger team
rosters are used, the number of players may be increased.

4.3.3.1 The number must be placed in the centre of the front and back of the
jersey. The colour and brightness of the numbers must contrast with
the colour and brightness of the jerseys.

4.3.3.2 The number must be at least 15 cm high on the chest and at least
20 cm high on the back. The stripe forming the numbers must be at
least 2 cm wide.

4.3.4 The team captain must have a strip 8 x 2 cm on his jersey
underlining the number on the chest.

4.3.5 It is forbidden to wear jerseys of a different colour from that of the
other players (except for Liberos) and/or without official numbers.

4.4 CHANGE OF EQUIPMENT

The first referee may authorize one or more players:

4.4.1 to play barefoot;

4.4.2 to change wet or damaged jerseys between sets or after a
substitution,

provided that the colour, design and number of the new jerseys are the
same;

4.4.3 to play in training suits in cold weather, provided that they are of the
same colour and design for the whole team (except for the Liberos)
and are numbered in accordance with Rule 4.3.3.

4.5 FORBIDDEN OBJECTS

4.5.1 It is forbidden to wear objects that may cause injury or give a player
an artificial advantage.

4.5.2 The wearing of glasses or contact lenses is at the player’s own risk.

4.5.3 Compression pads (padded protective devices) may be worn for
protection or support.

For FIVB, world and official senior competitions, these devices must be
the same colour as the corresponding part of the uniform. Black,
white or neutral colours may also be used, provided that all players
wear the same colour.

5 TEAM LEADERSHIP

Both the team captain and the coach are responsible for the behaviour
and discipline of their team members.

Liberos may be either team captains or game captains.

5.1 CAPTAIN

5.1.1 Before the match, the team captain represents his team in the coin
toss and then signs the score sheet.

5.1.2 During the match and while on the court, the team captain is the
game captain. If the team captain is not on the court, the coach or the
team captain must designate another player on the court

If the team captain is not on the court, the coach or the team captain
must designate another player on the court to act as game captain.
This game captain retains this responsibility until he/she is substituted,
until the team captain returns, or until the end of the set.

5.2 COACH

When the ball is out of play, only the game captain is entitled to speak
to the referees:

5.1.2.1 to request an explanation of the application or interpretation of the
rules and also to convey the wishes or questions of his/her teammates.
If the game captain is not satisfied with the first referee’s
explanation, he/she may lodge a protest against this decision and
must immediately inform the first referee that he/she reserves the
right to record an official protest on the score sheet at the end of the
match;

5.1.2.2 to request authorization:
  a) to change all or part of the equipment,
  b) to check the positions of the teams,
  c) to check the condition of the floor, net, ball, etc.;

5.1.2.3 in the absence of the coach, unless the team has an assistant coach
who has assumed the coach’s duties, to request time‑outs and
substitutions.

5.1.3 At the end of the match, the team captain:

5.1.3.1 thanks the referees and signs the score sheet to confirm the result;

5.1.3.2 if he/she has informed the first referee in due time, may confirm an
official protest concerning the application or interpretation of the
rules by the referee and have it recorded on the score sheet.

5.2.1 Throughout the match, the coach directs his/her team’s play from
outside the playing area. He/she selects the starting line‑up and
substitute players, and requests time‑outs. In performing these duties,
his/her contact official is the second referee.

5.2.2 Before the match, the coach records the names and numbers of his
players on the score sheet and then signs it.

5.2.3 DURING THE MATCH, the coach:

5.2.3.1 before each set, hands the second referee or the scorer the
properly completed and signed line‑up sheet(s); when tablet
applications are used, the electronic transmission of the line‑up is
considered official automatically;

5.2.3.2 sits on the team bench closest to the scorer but may leave it;

5.2.3.3 requests time‑outs and substitutions;

5.2.3.4 may, like other team members, give instructions to the players on the
court. The coach may give these instructions while standing in or
moving through the free zone in front of his team’s bench, from the
extension of the attack line to the warm‑up area, if it is located in the
corner of the competition control zone, without disturbing or delaying
the match. If the warm‑up area is located behind the team bench, the
coach may move from the extension of the attack line to the end of
his team’s playing area, provided he does not obstruct the line
judges’ view.

5.3 ASSISTANT COACH

5.3.1 The assistant coach sits on the team bench but has no right to
interfere in the match.

5.3.2 If the coach must leave the team for any reason, including a sanction,
except for entering the court as a player, an assistant coach may
assume the coach’s duties for the duration of the coach’s absence,
after the game captain has informed the referees of this.

6 SCORING A POINT, WINNING A SET AND THE MATCH

CHAPTER 3
FORMAT OF THE GAME

6.1 SCORING A POINT
6.2 WINNING A SET

6.1.1 Point

A team scores a point:

6.1.1.1 by successfully grounding the ball on the opponent’s court;

6.1.1.2 when the opponent commits a fault;

6.1.1.3 when the opponent receives a penalty.

6.1.2 Fault

A team commits a fault when it makes a playing action contrary to the
rules (or otherwise violates the rules). The referees judge the faults and
award the consequences in accordance with the rules:

6.1.2.1 if two or more faults are committed successively, only the first fault is
counted;

6.1.2.2 if two or more faults are committed simultaneously by opponents,
then

In this case, a DOUBLE FAULT is signalled and the rally is replayed.

6.1.3 Rally and completed rally

A rally is the sequence of playing actions from the moment the server
hits the service until the ball is out of play. A completed rally is the
sequence of playing actions that results in a point.

This includes:
– the imposition of a sanction;
– loss of service for a service hit after the time limit.

6.1.3.1 If the serving team wins the rally, it scores a point and continues to
serve.

6.1.3.2 If the receiving team wins the rally, it scores a point and must serve
next.

A set (except the deciding 5th set) is won by the team that first scores
25 points with a minimum lead of two points. When the score is
24–24, the game continues until a two‑point lead is reached (26–24,
27–25, etc.).

6.3 WINNING THE MATCH

6.3.1 The match is won by the team that wins three sets.

6.3.2 If the score is tied at 2–2, the deciding 5th set is played to 15 points
with a minimum lead of 2 points.

6.4 STANDARD AND INCOMPLETE TEAM

6.4.1 If a team, after being summoned to play, refuses to play, it is declared
defaulted.

and loses the match with the result 0–3 for the match and 0–25 for each
set.

6.4.2 A team that, without justifiable reason, does not appear on the court
at the scheduled time is declared late with the same result as in
Rule 6.4.1.

6.4.3 A team declared INCOMPLETE for a set or the match loses that set
or match. The opponent is awarded the points, or the points and sets
necessary to win the set or match. The incomplete team retains its
points and sets.

7 STRUCTURE OF PLAY

7.1 THE TOSS

Before the match, the first referee carries out a toss to determine the
first service and the sides of the court for the first set.

If a deciding set is to be played, a new toss is carried out.

7.1.1 The toss is conducted in the presence of both team captains.

7.1.2 The winner of the toss chooses:

EITHER

7.1.2.1 the right to serve or receive the service,

OR

7.1.2.2 the side of the court.

The loser takes the remaining choice.

7.2 OFFICIAL WARM‑UP

7.2.1 Before the match, if the teams have previously had a court
exclusively at their disposal, they are entitled to a 6‑minute official
joint warm‑up at the net; otherwise they may have 10 minutes.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the teams are entitled to a
10‑minute joint warm‑up at the net.

7.2.2 If either team captain requests a separate (consecutive) official
warm‑up at the net, each team is given either 3 or 5 minutes.

7.2.3 For consecutive official warm‑ups, the team that has the first service
warms up at the net first.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, all players must wear
playing uniforms throughout the protocol procedures and the warm‑up.

7.3 TEAM STARTING LINE‑UP

7.3.1 There must always be six players per team in play.

The team starting line‑up indicates the order in which the players stand
on the court. This order must be maintained throughout the set.

7.3.2 Before the start of each set, the coach must indicate his team’s
starting line‑up on a line‑up sheet or via an electronic device, if used.
The properly completed and signed sheet is submitted to the second
referee or the scorer, or is sent electronically directly to the e‑scorer.

7.3.3 Players not included in a set’s starting line‑up are the substitutes for
that set (except the Liberos).

7.3.4 Once the line‑up sheet has been delivered to the second referee or the
scorer, no change in the line‑up may be authorized without a regular
substitution.

7.3.5 Discrepancies between the positions of the players on the court and on
the line‑up sheet …

Line‑up sheets are handled as follows:

7.3.5.1 If such a discrepancy is discovered before the start of the set, the
positions of the players must be corrected according to the
line‑up sheet – no sanction is applied.

7.3.5.2 If, before the start of the set, it is discovered that a player on the
court is not listed on the line‑up sheet for that set, this player must
be substituted so that the court matches the line‑up sheet – no
sanction is applied.

7.3.5.3 However, if the coach wishes to keep the unregistered player on the
court, he/she must request the corresponding regular substitution(s)
using the official hand signal; the substitution(s) are then recorded
on the score sheet.

If a discrepancy between the players’ positions and the line‑up sheet
is discovered later, the faulty team must resume the correct
positions. The opponent’s points remain valid and the opponent is
awarded an additional point and the next service. All points scored by
the faulty team from the moment of the fault until it is discovered are
cancelled.

7.3.5.4 If a player is on the court who is not entered on the team list, the
opponent’s points remain valid and the opponent is awarded an
additional point and a service. The offending team loses all points
and/or sets (possibly 0–25) that it has won from the moment the
unregistered player entered the court, and must submit an amended
line‑up sheet and send a newly registered player onto the court in
place of the unregistered player.

7.4 POSITIONS

At the moment the server hits the ball, each team must be within its
own court (except for the server). The players of the serving team
must be in the correct rotational order when the service is hit.

However, the players of the serving team are free to occupy any
position for the service.

7.4.1 The players’ positions are numbered as follows:

7.4.1.1 the three players along the net are front‑row players and occupy
positions 4 (front‑left), 3 (front‑centre) and 2 (front‑right);

7.4.1.2 the other three are back‑row players and occupy positions 5 (back‑left),
6 (back‑centre) and 1 (back‑right).

7.4.2 Relative positions between players:

7.4.2.1 Each back‑row player must be further from the centre line than the
corresponding front‑row player.

7.4.2.2 The front‑row and back‑row players must be placed laterally in the
order specified in Rule 7.4.1.

7.4.3 The players’ positions are determined and controlled by the
positions of their feet in contact with the ground (the last contact with
the floor establishes the player’s position), as follows:

7.4.3.1 Each back‑row player must have both feet on the same level as, or
further from the centre line than, the corresponding front‑row
player’s front foot (i.e. at least part of one foot further from the
centre line than that front foot).

7.4.3.2 Each right‑side (left‑side) player must have both feet on the same
level as, or closer to the right (left) sideline than the right (left) foot
of any other player in that row.

After the service hit, players of both teams may move and occupy any
position on their own court and in the free zone.

7.5 POSITIONAL FAULTS

7.5.1 A team commits a positional fault if a player is not in his/her correct
position at the moment the service is hit. If a player is on the court as
a result of an illegal substitution and play has resumed, this counts as
a positional fault with the consequences of an illegal substitution.

7.5.2 If the server commits a service fault at the moment of the service hit,
the server’s fault is counted before any positional fault.

7.5.3 If the service becomes faulty after the service hit, the positional fault
is counted.

7.5.4 A positional fault has the following consequences:

7.5.4.1 the team is penalized with a point and the next service for the
opponent;

7.5.4.2 the players’ positions must be corrected.

7.6 ROTATION

7.6.1 The rotation order is determined by the team’s starting line‑up and is
controlled by the serving order and the players’ positions during the
set.

7.6.2 When the serving team wins the right to serve, its players rotate one
position clockwise: the player in position 2 moves to position 1 to
serve, the player in position 1 moves to position 6, and so on.

7.7 ROTATION FAULT

7.7.1 A rotation fault is committed when the service is not carried out in
accordance with the rotation order. It has the following consequences
in sequence:

7.7.1.1 the scorer interrupts the game with the buzzer; the opponent is
awarded a point and the next service.

If the rotation fault is discovered only after the end of the rally which
began with a rotation fault, the opponent is awarded only a single
point, regardless of the result of that rally.

7.7.1.2 the rotation order of the faulty team must be corrected.

7.7.2 In addition, the scorer must determine the exact moment when the
fault occurred, and all points scored thereafter by the faulty team
must be cancelled. The opponent’s points remain valid.

If this moment cannot be determined, no points are cancelled and a
point and service for the opponent are the only sanction.

8 STATES OF PLAY

CHAPTER 4
PLAYING ACTIONS

8.1 BALL IN PLAY

The ball is in play from the moment of the service hit, after the first
referee’s whistle, until the ball is out of play.

8.2 BALL OUT OF PLAY

The ball is out of play at the moment of the fault whistled by one of the
referees; if no fault is committed, it is out of play at the moment of the
whistle.

8.3 BALL "IN"

The ball is "in" when any part of the ball touches the court, including the
boundary lines, at any time of its contact with the floor.

8.4 BALL "OUT"

The ball is "out" when:

8.4.1 all parts of the ball which touch the floor are completely outside the
boundary lines;

8.4.2 it touches an object outside the court, the ceiling or a person not in
play;

8.4.3 it touches the antennas, cables, posts or the net itself outside the side
bands;

8.4.4 it crosses the vertical plane of the net, either partially or completely,
outside the crossing space, except in the case of Rule 10.1.2;

8.4.5 it passes completely under the net through the lower space.

9 PLAYING THE BALL

9.1 TEAM HITS
9.2 CHARACTERISTICS OF THE HIT

Each team must play within its own court and playing space (exception:
Rule 10.1.2). However, the ball may be played back from beyond its own
free zone and over the scorer’s table throughout its trajectory.

A hit is any contact with the ball by a player in play.

For returning the ball, a team is entitled to a maximum of three hits (in
addition to the block). If more are used, the team commits the fault of
"FOUR HITS".

9.1.1 SUCCESSIVE CONTACTS

A player may not hit the ball twice in succession (exceptions: Rules
9.2.3, 14.2 and 14.4.2).

9.1.2 SIMULTANEOUS CONTACTS

Two or three players may touch the ball at the same moment.

9.1.2.1 When two (or three) teammates touch the ball simultaneously, this
counts as two (or three) hits (except for a block). If they reach for the
ball but only one of them touches it, one hit is counted. A collision
between players is not a fault.

9.1.2.2 When two opponents hit the ball simultaneously over the net and the
ball remains in play, the team receiving the ball is entitled to three
additional hits. If such a ball goes "out", the fault is on the opponent’s
side.

9.1.2.3 If simultaneous hits by two opponents over the net result in a prolonged

If simultaneous hits by two opponents over the net result in a
prolonged contact with the ball, play continues even if the contact ends
over the opponent’s court.

9.1.3 ASSISTED HIT

Within the playing area, a player is not permitted to take support from
a teammate or a structure/object in order to hit the ball.

However, a player who is about to commit a fault (touching the net,
crossing the centre line, etc.) may be stopped or held back by a
teammate.

9.2 CHARACTERISTICS OF THE HIT

9.2.1 The ball may touch any part of the body.

9.2.2 The ball must not be caught and/or thrown. It may rebound in any
direction.

9.2.3 The ball may touch various parts of the body, provided the contacts
occur simultaneously. Exceptions:

9.2.3.1 When blocking, successive contacts by one or more players are
permitted, provided that the contacts occur during a single action.

9.2.3.2 On the team’s first hit, the ball may touch various parts of the body in
succession, provided that the contacts occur during a single action.

9.3 FAULTS IN PLAYING THE BALL

9.3.1 FOUR HITS: a team hits the ball four times before returning it.

9.3.2 ASSISTED HIT: a player takes support from a teammate or a
structure/object in order to hit the ball within the playing area.

9.3.3 CATCH: the ball is caught and/or thrown; it does not rebound from the
hit.

9.3.4 DOUBLE CONTACT: a player hits the ball twice in succession or the ball
touches various parts of the player’s body in succession.

10 BALL AT THE NET

10.1 BALL CROSSING THE NET

10.1.1 A ball sent to the opponent’s court must cross the net within the
crossing space. The crossing space is that part of the vertical plane of
the net which is limited as follows:

10.1.1.1 below, by the top of the net;

10.1.1.2 at the sides, by the antennas and their imaginary extensions;

10.1.1.3 above, by the ceiling.

10.1.2 A ball coming from the team’s first hit which has crossed the plane of
the net, totally or partially, outside the crossing space into the
opponent’s free zone, may be played back within the team’s three hits,
provided that:

10.1.2.1 the opponent’s court is not touched by the player (except as in
Rule 11.2.2.1);

10.1.2.2 when it is played back, the ball again crosses the net plane totally
or partially outside the crossing space on the same side of the court;
otherwise it is "out". The opponent is not allowed to prevent such an
action.

10.1.2.3 a ball which has crossed, totally or partially, outside the crossing
space into the opponent’s free zone and results from the team’s
second or third hit may not be played back and is "out" at the moment
it crosses the plane of the net.

10.1.3 A ball moving through the lower space towards the opponent’s court
is in play until it has completely crossed the vertical plane of the net.

10.2 BALL TOUCHES THE NET

When crossing the net, the ball may touch it.

10.3 BALL IN THE NET

10.3.1 A ball driven into the net may be recovered within the limits of the
team’s three hits.

10.3.2 If the ball tears the mesh of the net or causes it to break or becomes
caught in it, the rally is cancelled and replayed.

11 PLAYERS AT THE NET

11.1 CROSSING BEYOND THE NET

11.1.1 When blocking, a player may touch the ball beyond the net, provided
that he/she does not interfere with the opponent’s play before or
during the opponent’s attack hit.

11.1.2 After an attack hit, a player is permitted to pass his/her hand beyond
the net, provided that the initial contact with the ball was made within
his/her own playing space and the ball was not caught or thrown.

11.2 PENETRATION UNDER THE NET

11.2.1 Penetration into the opponent’s space under the net is permitted,
provided that it does not interfere with the opponent’s play.

11.2.2 Penetration into the opponent’s court beyond the centre line:

11.2.2.1 touching the opponent’s court with a foot (feet) is permitted,
provided that some part of the penetrating foot (feet) remains in
contact with or directly above the centre line, and this action does not
interfere with the opponent’s play.

11.2.2.2 Touching the opponent’s court with any part of the body above the
feet is permitted, provided that it does not interfere with the
opponent’s play.

11.2.3 A player may enter the opponent’s court after the ball is out of play.

11.2.4 Players may enter the opponent’s free zone, provided that they do
not interfere with the opponent’s play.

11.3 CONTACT WITH THE NET

11.3.1 Contact with the net by a player between the antennas, while
playing the ball, is a fault.

Playing the ball includes (among other actions) take‑off, the hit (or
attempt) and the landing, preparing for a new action.

11.3.2 Players may touch the posts, cables or any other object outside the
antennas, including the net itself, provided that this does not interfere
with play (exception: Rule 9.1.3).

11.3.3 When the ball is driven into the net and causes it to touch an
opponent, no fault is committed.

11.4 PLAYER FAULTS AT THE NET

11.4.1 A player touches the ball or an opponent in the opponent’s space
before or during the opponent’s attack hit.

11.4.2 A player interferes with the opponent’s play by penetrating into the
opponent’s space under the net.

11.4.3 A player’s foot (feet) completely penetrates into the opponent’s
court.

11.4.4 A player interferes with play by (among others):
– touching the net between the antennas or the antenna itself while
  playing the ball,
– using the net between the antennas as a support or stabilizing aid,
– gaining an unfair advantage over the opponent by touching the net,
– actions that hinder the opponent’s legitimate attempt to play the
  ball,
– catching / holding the net.

Any player who is near the ball while it is being played, and who
himself/herself attempts to play the ball, is considered a player in the
action, even if he/she does not touch the ball.

However, touching the net outside the antenna is not considered a
fault (exception: Rule 9.1.3).

12 SERVICE

The service is the act of putting the ball into play by the back‑right
player who is in the service zone.

12.1 FIRST SERVICE IN A SET

12.1.1 The first service of the first set, as well as that of the deciding 5th
set, is executed by the team determined by the toss.

12.1.2 The other sets are started with the service of the team that did not
serve first in the previous set.

12.2 SERVICE ORDER

12.2.1 The players must serve in the order recorded on the line‑up sheet.

12.2.2 After the first service in a set, the server is determined as follows:

12.2.2.1 If the serving team wins the rally, the player (or his/her substitute)
who previously served, serves again.

12.2.2.2 If the receiving team wins the rally, it gains the right to serve and
rotates before the actual service. The player who moves from front‑right
to back‑right serves.

12.3 AUTHORIZATION OF THE SERVICE

The first referee authorizes the service after having checked that both
teams are ready to play and that the server is in possession of the ball.

12.4 EXECUTION OF THE SERVICE

12.4.1 The ball must be hit with one hand or any part of the arm after being
tossed or released from the hand(s).

12.4.2 Only one toss or release of the ball is allowed. Dribbling or moving
the ball in the hands is permitted.

12.4.3 At the moment of the service hit or the jump for a jump service, the
server may not touch the court (including the end line) or the floor
outside the service zone.

After the hit, he/she may step or land outside the service zone or
inside the court.

12.4.4 The server must hit the ball within 8 seconds after the first referee’s
whistle.

12.4.5 A service executed before the referee’s whistle is cancelled and
repeated.

12.5 SCREENING

12.5.1 Players of the serving team must not prevent their opponents from
seeing the server and the trajectory of the ball by individual or
collective screening.

12.5.2 A player or group of players of the serving team forms a screen by
waving the arms, jumping, or moving sideways during the execution
of the service, or by standing as a group in such a way that both the
service and the trajectory of the ball are hidden until the ball crosses
the vertical plane of the net. If both the server and the trajectory are
visible for the receiving team, this is not a screen.

12.5.3 Any player of the serving team is forbidden to raise the hands above
the head during the service until the ball has crossed the net.

The first referee may warn (advise) a team via the game captain if he
suspects that the team is intentionally screening.

12.6 FAULTS DURING THE SERVICE

12.6.1 Service faults committed at the moment of the service hit

The following faults lead to a service loss, even if the opponent is not
in the correct position. The server:

12.6.1.1 violates the service order;

12.6.1.2 does not execute the service properly.

12.6.2 Service faults after the service hit

After the ball has been correctly hit, the service becomes faulty (unless
a player is in the wrong position) if the ball:

12.6.2.1 touches a player of the serving team or fails to cross completely the
vertical plane of the net within the crossing space;

12.6.2.2 goes "out";

12.6.2.3 passes over a screen.

12.7 SERVICE FAULTS AND POSITIONAL FAULTS

12.7.1 If the server commits a service fault at the moment of the service hit
(improper execution, wrong rotation order, etc.) and the opponent is
not in the correct position, the service fault is penalized.

12.7.2 If the execution of the service was correct but the service then
becomes faulty (goes out, passes over a screen, etc.), the positional
fault occurred first and is penalized.

13 ATTACK HIT

13.1 CHARACTERISTICS OF THE ATTACK HIT

13.1.1 All actions that direct the ball towards the opponent, except for the
service and block, are considered attack hits.

13.1.2 During an attack hit, tipping is only permitted if the ball is cleanly hit
and not caught or thrown.

13.1.3 An attack hit is completed at the moment the ball has completely
crossed the vertical plane of the net or when it is touched by an
opponent.

13.2 RESTRICTIONS OF THE ATTACK HIT

13.2.1 A front‑row player may perform an attack hit at any height, provided
that the contact with the ball has been made within his/her own
playing space (except Rules 13.2.4 and 13.3.6).

13.2.2 A back‑row player may perform an attack hit at any height from
behind the front zone:

13.2.2.1 the player’s foot (feet) must neither touch nor cross the attack line at
take‑off;

13.2.2.2 the player may land in the front zone after the hit.

13.2.3 A back‑row player may also perform an attack hit from the front zone
if, at the moment of contact, part of the ball is lower than the top of
the net.

13.2.4 No player may complete an attack hit on the opponent’s service when
the ball is in the front zone and entirely above the top of the net.

13.3 FAULTS OF THE ATTACK HIT

13.3.1 A player hits the ball into the opponent’s court outside the boundaries.

13.3.2 A player hits the ball "out".

13.3.3 A back‑row player performs an attack hit from the front zone when
the ball is entirely above the top of the net at the moment of the hit.

13.3.4 A player performs an attack hit on the opponent’s service when the
ball is in the front zone and entirely above the top of the net.

13.3.5 A Libero performs an attack hit when, at the moment of contact, the ball is entirely above the top of the net.

13.3.6 A player completes an attack hit from above the net when the ball comes from an overhand finger pass by a Libero in his/her front zone.

14 BLOCK

14.1 BLOCKING

14.1.1 Blocking is the action of players close to the net to intercept the ball coming from the opponent by reaching higher than the top of the net, regardless of the height of contact with the ball. Only front‑row players may complete a block, and at the moment of ball contact some part of the body must be higher than the top of the net.

14.1.2 BLOCK ATTEMPT
A block attempt is the action of blocking without touching the ball.

14.1.3 COMPLETED BLOCK
A block is completed when the ball is touched by a blocker.

14.1.4 COLLECTIVE BLOCK
A collective block is executed by two or three players close together and is completed when one of them touches the ball.

14.2 BLOCK CONTACT

Successive (quick and continuous) contacts with the ball by one or more blockers are permitted, provided that the contacts occur during a single blocking action.

14.3 BLOCKING WITHIN THE OPPONENT’S SPACE

When blocking, the player may extend his/her hands and arms beyond the net, provided that this action does not interfere with the opponent’s play. It is not permitted to touch the ball beyond the net before the opponent has completed an attack hit.

14.4 BLOCK AND TEAM HITS

14.4.1 A block contact is not counted as a team hit. Consequently, after a block contact the team still has the right to three hits to return the ball.

14.4.2 The first hit after the block may be executed by any player, including the one who touched the ball during the block.

14.5 BLOCKING THE SERVICE

It is forbidden to block the opponent’s service.

14.6 BLOCKING FAULTS

14.6.1 A blocker touches the ball in the opponent’s space before the opponent’s attack hit.

14.6.2 A back‑row player or a Libero completes a block or participates in a completed block.

14.6.3 Blocking the opponent’s service.

14.6.4 The ball is sent "out" from the block.

14.6.5 Blocking the ball in the opponent’s space from outside the antenna.

14.6.6 A Libero attempts an individual or collective block.

15 INTERRUPTIONS

CHAPTER 5
INTERRUPTIONS, DELAYS AND INTERVALS

An interruption is the time between a completed rally and the first referee’s whistle for the next service.

The only regular game interruptions are TIME‑OUTS and SUBSTITUTIONS.

Each team is entitled to a maximum of two time‑outs and six substitutions per set.

15.2 ORDER OF REGULAR GAME INTERRUPTIONS

15.2.1 A request for one or two time‑outs and a request for substitution by either team may follow each other within the same interruption.

15.2.2 However, a team is not entitled to request substitutions successively within the same interruption. Two or more players may be substituted simultaneously within a single request.

15.2.3 Between two separate substitution requests by the same team there must be a completed rally. (Exception: a forced substitution due to injury or expulsion/disqualification (15.5.2, 15.7, 15.8)).

15.2.4 It is not permitted to request a regular game interruption after a request during the same interruption (i.e. before the end of the next completed rally) has been refused and sanctioned with a delay warning.

15.3 REQUESTING REGULAR GAME INTERRUPTIONS

15.3.1 Regular game interruptions may be requested only by the coach, or in his/her absence by the assistant coach or the game captain.

15.3.2 A substitution before the start of a set is permitted and should be considered a regular substitution.

15.4 TIME‑OUTS

15.4.1 Time‑outs must be requested with the official hand signal when the ball
is out of play and before the whistle for the service. All requested time‑outs
last 30 seconds.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the length of time‑outs may be
adjusted if the FIVB approves this at the organizer’s request.

In FIVB, world and official competitions, it is mandatory to use the buzzer
and then the hand signal to request a time‑out.

15.4.2 During all time‑outs, players must go to the free zone near their own
team bench.

15.5 SUBSTITUTION

15.5.1 A substitution is the act by which a player, other than the Libero or his/her
replacement, enters the match, after being recorded by the scorer, to
occupy the position of another player who must leave the court at that
moment.

15.5.2 If the substitution is forced by an injury to a player during play, the
coach (or game captain) may give the corresponding hand signal.

15.6 LIMITATION OF SUBSTITUTIONS

15.6.1 A player in the starting line‑up may leave the court but only once in a
set, and may re‑enter but only once in that set, and only in his/her
previous position in the line‑up.

15.6.2 A substitute may enter the match in place of a starting player only once
per set, and may be replaced only by the same starting player.

15.7 EXCEPTIONAL SUBSTITUTION

A player (other than a Libero) who cannot continue playing because of
injury/illness or expulsion/disqualification must be legally substituted.
If this is not possible, the team is entitled to make an EXCEPTIONAL
substitution, which goes beyond the limits of Rule 15.6.

An exceptional substitution means that any player who is not on the
court at the moment of the injury/illness/expulsion/disqualification,
except for the Libero, the second Libero or the regular substitute for
that player, may be substituted for the
injured/ill/expelled/disqualified player. The player who has been
exceptionally substituted out because of injury/illness/expulsion may
not re‑enter the match.

An exceptional substitution can in no case be counted as a regular
substitution, but it must be recorded on the score sheet as part of the
total number of substitutions in the set and in the match.

15.8 SUBSTITUTE FOR EXPULSION OR DISQUALIFICATION

An expelled or disqualified player must be immediately replaced by a
legal substitution.

If this is not possible, the team has the right to make an exceptional
substitution. If this is still not possible, the team is declared
INCOMPLETE.

15.9 ILLEGAL SUBSTITUTION

15.9.1 A substitution is illegal if it exceeds the limits specified in Rule 15.6
(except in the case of Rule 15.7), or if an unregistered player is
involved.

15.9.2 If a team has made an illegal substitution and play has resumed, the
following procedure applies, in order:

15.9.2.1 the team is penalized with a point and the next service for the
opponent;

15.9.2.2 the substitution must be corrected;

15.9.2.3 all points scored by the faulty team from the moment of the fault are
cancelled; the opponent’s points remain valid.

15.10 SUBSTITUTION PROCEDURE

15.10.1 The substitution must be carried out within the substitution zone.

15.10.2 A substitution lasts only the time necessary for recording the
substitution on the score sheet and for the players to enter and leave
the court.

15.10.3.1 The actual substitution request begins when the substitute player(s)
arrive(s) ready to play in the substitution zone during an interruption.
The coach does not need to give a hand signal for the substitution,
except when the substitution is due to an injury or before the start of
the set.

15.10.3.2 If the player is not ready at the moment of the request, the
substitution …

15.10.3.2 If the player is not ready at the moment of the request, the substitution is not granted and the team is sanctioned for delay.

15.10.3.3 The substitution request is confirmed and announced by the scorer or the second referee with the buzzer and whistle. The second referee authorizes the substitution.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, numbered paddles are used to facilitate substitutions (unless electronic devices are used to transmit data to the scorer).

16 DELAYS TO THE GAME

16.1 TYPES OF DELAYS

16.2 DELAY SANCTIONS

15.10.4 When a team intends to make more than one substitution at the same time, all substitute players must enter the substitution zone simultaneously and be included in the same request. In this case, the substitutions must be carried out successively, one pair of players at a time. If one substitution is illegal, the legal one(s) is/are granted and the illegal one(s) is/are refused and subject to a delay sanction.

15.11 ILLEGAL REQUESTS

15.11.1 It is illegal to request a regular game interruption:

15.11.1.1 during a rally or at the moment of, or after, the whistle for service;

15.11.1.2 by an unauthorized team member.

15.11.1.3 for a second substitution by the same team within the same interruption (i.e. before the end of the next completed rally), except in the case of injury/illness/expulsion/disqualification of a player in play;

15.11.1.4 after the allowable number of time‑outs and substitutions has been exhausted.

15.11.2 The first illegal request by a team in a match, which does not affect or delay the game, is rejected but must be recorded on the score sheet without further consequences.

15.11.3 Any further illegal request in the same match by the same team constitutes a delay.

A team’s illegal action that delays the resumption of the game is a delay and includes, among others:

16.1.1 delaying regular game interruptions;

16.1.2 prolonging interruptions after being instructed to resume play;

16.1.3 requesting an illegal substitution;

16.1.4 repeating an illegal request;

16.1.5 delaying the game by a team member.

16.2.1 'Delay warning' and 'delay penalty' are team sanctions.

16.2.1.1 Delay sanctions remain in force for the entire match.

16.2.1.2 All delay sanctions are recorded on the score sheet.

17 EXTRAORDINARY GAME INTERRUPTIONS

17.1 INJURY / ILLNESS

17.2 EXTERNAL INTERFERENCE

17.3 PROLONGED INTERRUPTIONS

16.2.2 The first delay in a match by a team member is sanctioned with a 'DELAY WARNING'.

16.2.3 The second and subsequent delays of any kind by a member of the same team in the same match constitute a fault and are sanctioned with a 'DELAY PENALTY': a point and service for the opponent.

16.2.4 Delay penalties imposed before or between sets are applied in the following set.

17.1.1 If a serious accident occurs during the match, the referee must immediately stop play and allow medical assistance onto the court.

The rally is then replayed.

17.1.2 If an injured/ill player cannot be legally or exceptionally substituted, the player is given a recovery time of 3 minutes, but not more than once for the same player in the match.

If the player does not recover, the team is declared incomplete.

If external interference occurs during the match, play must be interrupted and the rally is replayed.

17.3.1 If unforeseen circumstances interrupt the match, the first referee, the organizer and the control committee, if present, decide on the measures to restore normal conditions.

17.3.2 If one or more interruptions occur which in total do not exceed 4 hours:

17.3.2.1 If the match is resumed on the same court, the interrupted set is continued normally with the same score, the same players (except expelled or …).

17.3.2.2 If the match is resumed on a different court, the interrupted set is cancelled and replayed with the same team members and the same starting line‑ups (except expelled or disqualified players), while all sanctions recorded remain in force. Previously completed sets retain their score.

17.3.3 If one or more interruptions occur which in total exceed 4 hours, the entire match is replayed.

18 INTERVALS AND CHANGE OF COURTS

18.1 INTERVALS

An interval is the time between sets. All intervals last three minutes.

During this time, the change of courts and the team line‑ups are recorded on the score sheet.

The interval between the second and third sets may be extended up to 10 minutes at the organizer’s request, subject to approval by the competent body.

18.2 CHANGE OF COURTS

18.2.1 After each set, the teams change courts, except before the deciding set.

18.2.2 In the deciding set, the teams change courts immediately once the leading team reaches 8 points, keeping the same player positions.

19 THE LIBERO PLAYER

CHAPTER 6
THE LIBERO PLAYER

19.1 DESIGNATION OF THE LIBERO

19.1.1 Each team has the right to designate up to two Liberos from the list of players on the score sheet.

For FIVB, world and official senior competitions, TWO Liberos must be listed if a team has more than 12 players on the score sheet.

19.1.2 All Liberos must be recorded on the score sheet in the lines provided for them.

19.1.3 The Libero on the court is the acting Libero. If there is another Libero, he/she is the second Libero for the team.

Only one Libero may be on the court at a time.

19.2 EQUIPMENT

The Libero(s) must wear a jersey (or a jacket/bib for a newly designated Libero) whose colour contrasts with that of the rest of the team. The Libero’s jersey must clearly distinguish him/her from the rest of the team. The two Liberos may wear different jerseys, which differ both from each other and from the rest of the team.

The Liberos’ jerseys must be numbered like those of the other players.

For FIVB, world and official competitions, the newly designated Libero should, where possible, wear the same style and colour of jersey as the original Libero, but must keep his/her own number.

19.3 ACTIONS INVOLVING THE LIBERO

19.3.1 Playing actions

19.3.1.1 The Libero may replace any player in a back‑row position.

19.3.1.2 He/she may only play as a back‑row player and may not complete an
attack hit from anywhere (including the court and free zone) if, at the
moment of contact, the ball is entirely above the top of the net.

19.3.1.3 He/she may not serve, block or attempt to block.

19.3.1.4 A player may not complete an attack hit when the ball is entirely
above the top of the net if the ball comes from an overhand finger
pass by the Libero in the Libero’s front zone. The ball may be freely
attacked if the Libero performs the same action from outside his/her
front zone.

19.3.2 Libero replacements

19.3.2.1 Libero replacements are not counted as substitutions.

They are unlimited, but there must be a completed rally between two
Libero replacements (unless a sanction causes the team to rotate and
the Libero moves to the fourth position, or the acting Libero becomes
unable to play, making the rally incomplete).

19.3.2.2 The regular substitute may be replaced by either of the two Liberos and may
replace either of them. The acting Libero may only be replaced by the regular
substitute for that position or by the second Libero.

19.3.2.3 At the beginning of each set, the Libero may enter the court only after the
second referee has checked the line‑up and authorized the Libero replacement
for a starting player.

19.3.2.4 Other Libero replacements may be made only when the ball is out of play
and before the whistle for service.

19.3.2.5 A Libero replacement made after the whistle for service but before the
service hit should not be refused; however, at the end of the rally the game
captain must be informed that this is not a legal procedure and that a
repetition will be sanctioned as a delay.

19.3.2.6 Any further late Libero replacements lead to an immediate interruption of
the game and the imposition of a delay penalty. Which team serves next is
determined by the nature of the delay penalty.

19.3.2.7 The Libero and the player being replaced may enter or leave the court only
through the Libero replacement zone.

19.3.2.8 Libero replacements must be recorded on the Libero control sheet (if
used) or on the electronic score sheet.

19.3.2.9 An illegal Libero replacement may include, among others:

– no completed rally between Libero replacements;
– the Libero is replaced by a player other than the second Libero or the
  regular substitute.

An illegal Libero replacement must be treated as an illegal substitution:

That is, if the illegal Libero replacement is noticed before the start of the
next rally, it is corrected by the referees and the team is sanctioned for
delay.

If the illegal Libero replacement is noticed after the service hit, the
consequences are the same as for an illegal substitution.

19.4 RE‑DESIGNATION OF A NEW LIBERO

19.4.1 The Libero becomes unable to play if he/she is injured, ill, expelled or
disqualified. The Libero may be declared unable to play by the coach or,
in his/her absence, by the assistant coach or the game captain.

19.4.2 Team with one Libero

19.4.2.1 If, under Rule 19.4.1, a team has only one Libero available, or has
registered only one Libero, and this Libero is declared unable to play,
the coach (or assistant coach, or the game captain if no coach is
present) may, for the remainder of the match, designate another
player (except for the regular substitute) who is not on the court at
the moment of re‑designation as the Libero.

19.4.2.2 If the acting Libero becomes unable to play, he/she may be replaced by
the regular substitute or directly on the court by a newly designated
Libero. A newly designated Libero may not play in any other position
for the remainder of the match.

If the Libero is not on the court when he/she is declared unable to
play, a new Libero may also be designated. The Libero declared unable
to play may not take any further part in the match.

19.4.2.3 The coach, or the assistant coach or the game captain if no coach is
present, contacts the second referee and informs him/her of the new
designation.

19.4.2.4 If a newly designated Libero becomes unable to play or is declared
unable to play, further re‑designations are permitted.

19.4.2.5 If the coach requests that the team captain be designated as the new
Libero, this is permitted.

19.4.2.6 In the case of a newly designated Libero, the number of the new player
must be recorded in the remarks section of the score sheet and on the
Libero control sheet (or the electronic score sheet, if used).

19.4.3 Team with two Liberos

19.4.3.1 If a team has two Liberos listed on the score sheet but one of them
cannot play, the team may play with only one Libero.

Re‑designation is only permitted if the remaining Libero becomes
unable to play.

19.5 SUMMARY

If the Libero is expelled or disqualified, he/she may be immediately replaced by the team’s second Libero. If the team has only one Libero, it has the right to re‑designate a new Libero.

21 MISCONDUCT AND ITS SANCTIONS

21.1 MINOR MISCONDUCT

Minor misconduct is not subject to sanctions. It is the first referee’s task to prevent the teams from reaching the sanctioning level.

This is done in two stages:

Stage 1: by a verbal warning through the game captain;

Stage 2: by using a YELLOW CARD for the relevant team member(s). This formal warning is not, in itself, a sanction but a symbol that the team member (and thus the team) has reached the sanctioning level for the match.

It is recorded on the score sheet but has no immediate consequences.

21.2 MISCONDUCT LEADING TO SANCTIONS

Incorrect behaviour by a team member towards officials, opponents, teammates or spectators is classified in three categories according to the seriousness of the offence:

21.2.1 Rude conduct: actions contrary to good manners or moral principles.

21.2.2 Offensive conduct: defamatory or insulting words or gestures, or any action expressing contempt.

21.2.3 Aggression: actual physical attack or aggressive or threatening behaviour.

21.3 SANCTION SCALE

According to the first referee’s judgement and depending on the seriousness of the offence, sanctions are imposed and recorded on the score sheet as follows: penalty, expulsion or disqualification.

21.3.1 Penalty

The first rude conduct by a team member in the match is sanctioned with a point and service for the opponent.

21.3.2 Expulsion

21.3.2.1 A team member penalized with expulsion must be legally/exceptionally substituted immediately if on the court and may not take part in the rest of the set and must go to the team dressing room, without further consequences for the match.

An expelled coach loses the right to intervene in the set and must go to the team dressing room until the end of the current set.

21.3.2.2 The first offensive conduct by a team member is sanctioned with expulsion without further consequences.

21.3.2.3 The second rude conduct by the same team member in the same match is sanctioned with expulsion without further consequences.

21.3.3 Disqualification

21.3.3.1 A team member penalized with disqualification must, if on the court, be legally/exceptionally substituted immediately and must go to the team dressing room for the rest of the match, without further consequences.

21.3.3.2 The first physical attack, or behaviour implying or threatening aggression, is sanctioned with disqualification without further consequences.

21.3.3.3 The second offensive conduct by the same team member in the same match …

21.3.3.4 The third rude conduct by the same team member in the same match is sanctioned with disqualification without further consequences.

21.4 APPLICATION OF SANCTIONS FOR MISCONDUCT

21.4.1 All sanctions for misconduct are individual sanctions that apply for the entire match and are recorded on the score sheet.

21.4.2 Repetition of misconduct by the same team member in the same match is penalized progressively (each further offence results in a more severe sanction for that team member).

21.4.3 No prior sanction is required for an expulsion or disqualification resulting from offensive or aggressive behaviour.

21.5 MISCONDUCT BEFORE AND BETWEEN SETS

Any misconduct committed before or between sets is sanctioned according to Rule 21.3 and the sanctions apply to the following set.

21.6 SUMMARY OF MISCONDUCT AND THE CARDS USED

Warning: no sanction – Level 1: verbal warning
Level 2: symbol Yellow Card

Penalty: sanction – symbol Red Card

Expulsion: sanction – symbol Red + Yellow cards together

Disqualification: sanction – symbol Red + Yellow cards separately

PART 3 – DEFINITIONS

The following terms are defined in this Part: zones, areas, lower space, crossing space, external space, substitution zone, FIVB exceptions, FIVB standards, fault, dribbling.

**Competition / control area**  
The competition / control area is a corridor around the court and the free zone that includes all spaces up to the outer …

… barriers or boundary fence. See Diagram 1a.

**Zones**  
These are sections within the playing area (i.e. the court and the free zone) defined for a specific purpose (or with particular restrictions). They include: front zone, service zone, substitution zone, free zone, back zone and Libero replacement zone.

**Areas**  
These are sections of the floor outside the free zone that have a specific function in the Rules. They include, for example, the warm‑up area.

**Lower space**  
This is the space bounded above by the bottom of the net and the cord joining it to the posts, laterally by the posts, and below by the playing surface.

**Crossing space**  
The crossing space is defined by:
- the horizontal band at the top of the net,
- the antennas and their extensions,
- the ceiling.

The ball must pass through the crossing space to reach the opponent’s court.

**External space**  
The external space is located in the vertical plane of the net outside the crossing and lower spaces.

**Substitution zone**  
This is the part of the free zone where substitutions are carried out.

**Unless, with the consent of FIVB**  
This statement recognises that, while there are regulations on standards and specifications for equipment and facilities, FIVB may occasionally make special provisions to promote volleyball or to test new conditions.

**FIVB standards**  
Technical specifications or limits set by FIVB for equipment manufacturers.

**Fault**  
(a) An illegal playing action.
(b) A rule violation that is not a playing action.

**Dribbling**  
Dribbling means letting the ball bounce (usually as preparation for tossing and serving). Other preparatory actions can include, among others, moving the ball from hand to hand.

**Ball retrievers**  
These are persons whose duty is to maintain the flow of the game by rolling the ball to the server between rallies.

**Floor wipers**  
These are staff whose duty is to keep the floor clean and, when necessary, dry after each rally using small towels.

**Rally point**  
This is the system in which a point is scored when a rally is won.

**Interval**  
The time between sets. The change of courts in the fifth (deciding) set is not considered an interval.

**Re‑designation**  
This is the process by which a Libero who cannot continue playing, or is declared "unable to play" by the team, is replaced in the Libero role by another player (except the regular substitute) who is not on the court at the moment of re‑designation.

**Substitution (Libero replacement)**  
This is the action by which a regular player leaves the court and one of the two Liberos (if there are two) takes his/her place. It may also include Libero‑for‑Libero exchanges. The regular player may then replace one of the two Liberos. Between such replacements there must be a completed rally …

… in which any Libero may participate.

**Interfering action**  
Any action that gives the opponent an advantage, or any action that prevents the opponent from playing the ball.

**O‑2bis**  
An official FIVB form for registering players and team officials. It must be presented at the preliminary inquiry.

**External object**  
An object or person outside the court, or close to the limit of the free playing space, that interferes with the flight of the ball. Examples: overhead lights, the referee’s chair, TV equipment, the scorer’s table, net posts. Antennas are not considered external objects, as they are part of the net.

**Substitution (regular)**  
The action by which a regular player leaves the court and another regular player takes his/her place.

**Team’s first hit**  
There are four situations in which a playing action is considered the team’s first hit:
- reception of the service;
- reception of an opponent’s attack hit;
- playing the ball that rebounds from the team’s own block;
- playing the ball that rebounds from the opponent’s block.
